Introduction.title: King of Spices
Introduction.origin: Indigenous to the tropical forests of Western Ghats of South India.
Introduction.economic_importance: One of the important and earliest known spices produced and exported from India. India accounts for 54% of the total area under pepper in the world but its share of production is only 26.6 %.

plant_description.branches: Vines branch horizontally from the nodes, do not attain length, but the fully-grown vines completely cover the standard presenting the appearance of a bush.
plant_description.leaves: Broadly lanceolate, but wide variations occur in leaf shape and are arranged alternately.
plant_description.inflorescence: A catkin produced at the nodes opposite to the upper leaves.
plant_description.flowers: Very minute. Monoecious or dioecious or hermophrodite forms occur in different varieties.
plant_description.fruit: A single seeded berry, which has a thin, soft pericarp surrounding the seed.
plant_description.maturity_period: Approximately six months to mature after flowering.

Introduction.spike_shedding_control: Spike shedding occurs to the extent of 14 to 65% causing considerable loss. Spraying of IAA 50 ppm or planofix 50 ppm and or zinc 0.5% at the time of berry setting stage reduces spike shedding.

climate.ideal_location: Hot and humid climate of submountanous tracts of Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats.
climate.altitude: From sea level upto 1500 meters above MSL.

soil.preference: Thrives best on virgin soil rich in organic matter.

Varieties.general_info: Majority of the cultivated types of pepper are monoecious. Over 75 cultivars of pepper are being cultivated in India.

Propagation.method: Propagated by cuttings raised mainly from the runner shoots.
Propagation.cuttings_source: Runner shoots from high yielding and healthy vines are kept coiled on wooden pegs fixed at the base of the vine. The shoots are separated in February-March.
Propagation.cuttings_preparation: After trimming the leaves, cuttings of 2 to 3 nodes each are planted. Cuttings from middle 1/3 of the shoots are desirable as they are high yielding.
Propagation.planting: Cuttings are planted either in nursery beds or polythene bags filled with fertile soil.
Propagation.care: Adequate shade is to be provided and irrigated frequently.
Propagation.readiness: The cuttings will strike roots and become ready for planting in May-June.
Propagation.lateral_branches: Seldom used for propagation, as vines are generally short lived and bushy. However, they are useful in raising pepper in pots.

Selection of site.land_type: Well drained level land and hill slopes are suitable.
Selection of site.slope_preference: When grown on a slopy land, avoid south-facing slopes. The lower half of north and north eastern slopes are preferred to protect vines from the scorching sun.

Cropping method.monocrop: Large scale cultivation on hill slopes by clearing jungle lands and planting standards for the vines.
Cropping method.mixed_crop: Grown with arecanut, coconut, mango, jack etc., where these trees serve as standards.
Cropping method.intercrop: Suitable as an intercrop in coffee estates where shade trees serve as good standards.

Planting.timing: Generally with the onset of the southwest monsoon. Can also be done during the north east monsoon if it is regular and well distributed.

pure_crop.standards: Erythrina stem cuttings of 2m length or its two years old seedlings are planted on receipt of early monsoon showers.
pure_crop.planting_cuttings: 2 or 3 rooted cuttings are planted around the base of the standard, nearly 30 cm away.

with_coconut_arecanut.distance_from_trunk: 100 to 120 cm away from the tree trunk.
with_coconut_arecanut.initial_support: Vines may be allowed to climb on a stick or pole about 2 m tall, tied to the trunk in a slanting position.
with_coconut_arecanut.transplanting_to_trunk: After one year, the vine is separated from the temporary stake, lower leaves are nipped off, and the vine is placed in a narrow trench (15 cm deep and wide) leading to the tree trunk. The growing tip is tied to the trunk and the rest of the vine in the trench is covered with soil.

Cultural practices.initial_growth: As cuttings grow, shoots are tied to the standards. Young vines should be protected from hot sun with artificial shade.
Cultural practices.shade_management: Regulation of shade by lopping the branches of standards is necessary for providing optimum light and for enabling the standards to grow straight.
Cultural practices.mulching: Adequate mulch with green leaf, sawdust, coir dust, or organic matter should be given towards the end of northeast monsoon. The base of the vines should not be disturbed.

from_fourth_year.lopping: Done carefully to regulate the height of the standards and to shade the pepper vines optimally. Excessive shading encourages pest infestation.
from_fourth_year.pruning: The top of the vine is normally pruned after it has reached the required height (e.g., 6 m) for convenience of picking.
from_fourth_year.digging: Two diggings are given: one during May-June and the other towards the end of southwest monsoon in October-November.
from_fourth_year.cover_crops: Growing cover crops like Calapogonium mucanoides, Mimosa invisa are recommended under West Coast conditions.

Manures and fertilisers.organic: About 10 kg of well rotten cattle manure or compost is given in April-May.

chemical_per_standard.vines_3_years_and_above: 100g N, 40g P2O5, and 140g K2O per standard annually in two split doses (April-May and August-September).

Manures and fertilisers.application: Manures are applied around the vines at a distance of 30 cm and forked into the soil.
Manures and fertilisers.lime: May be applied at the rate of 500 g per standard during April in alternate years.

harvesting.maturity_time: 6 to 8 months from flowering to ripening.
harvesting.season: November to February in the plains and January to March in the hills.
harvesting.indicator: When one or two berries on the spike turn bright or red, the whole spike is plucked.

black_pepper.process: Berries are separated from spikes by rubbing or trampling. They are then dried in the sun for 7 to 10 days until the outer skin becomes black and shrunken.
black_pepper.optional_treatment: For uniform colour, berries are dipped in boiling water for one minute before drying.

white_pepper.process: Spikes with fully ripe berries are filled in gunny bags and steeped in flowing water for about 7 days. The outer rind is then removed by rubbing. The cleaned seeds are dried for 3 to 4 days.
white_pepper.finishing: The dull white seeds are further cleaned by winnowing and polishing by rubbing with a cloth.

Yield.decline: Starts declining after 20 to 25 years, after which replanting is needed.
Yield.average_yield: One-hectare plantation of 7 to 8 years old gives about 800 to 1000 kg of black pepper.

pests.name: Pollu beetle (Longitarsus, nigripennis)
pests.symptoms: Adults feed on growing points, tender shoots, leaves, tender spikes and berries. Grubs bore into the berries and cause black colour and they crumble when pressed.

pests.name: Top shoot borer (Cydia hemidoxa)
pests.symptoms: Caterpillars bore into the tender shoots turning them to black and drying up.
pests.control_measures: Spray endosulfan 0.05% twice when new shoots emerge.

pests.name: Leaf gall thrips (Liothrips karnyi)
pests.symptoms: Thrips live in colonies within the tubular marginal galls induced by them. Such leaves become thick malformed, crinkled.

pests.name: Scale insects (Lepidosaphes piperis, Aspidiotus destructor)
pests.symptoms: Drying of the infested portion of the vine.

diseases.name: Quick wilt or foot rot (Phytophthora capsici)
diseases.symptoms: Pathogen infects leaves, spikes, collar region and roots. Collar infection causes sudden collapse of the vine, other symptoms are foliar yellowing and defoliation. High soil moisture and relative humidity during monsoon favour infection and spread.
diseases.control_measures: Removal of the infected dead vines and burn them, provide proper drainage, avoid damage to root system and stem of vines. Spray vine with 1% Bordeaux mixture and 0.25% Ridomil ziram alternatively and drench the basin with the same chemical twice, once before monsoon and one after monsoon.

diseases.name: Pollu disease (Collectotrichum gloeosporioides)
diseases.symptoms: Brown sunken patches seen in the young berries, develops characteristic cross splitting and finally turn to black in colour and dry.

diseases.name: Slow decline or slow wilt
diseases.cause: Soil borne fungi (Fusarium sp., Rhizoctonia sp., Pythium sp., Diplodia sp.), nematodes (Radopholus similis, Meloidogyne incognita)
diseases.symptoms: During dry months, foliar yellowing, defoliation and dieback symptoms appear. During monsoon some affected vines recover and put forth fresh foliage, then show decline symptoms again during dry months, thus gradually losing vigour and productivity.
diseases.control_measures: Remove the severely affected vines, treat the planting pit with phorate @15g or carbofuran @ 50g at the time of planting, and apply phorate @ 30g or carbofuran @100g/vine twice in a year.
